Binary Exploitation.description:
I got this sketchy ROM file from a friend. Can you retrieve the redacted part near the beginning?

```nc 3.91.17.218 9002```

_by gg_
Binary Exploitation.name: Game Boy TAS

Binary Exploitation.description:
`nc sgx.utctf.live 9000`

The `sim_binary` directory contains a binary built for sgx-simulated mode. This can be run on any processor provided that the package `sgx-sdk` is installed.

The `hw_binary` directory will not work unless you have an sgx-capable cpu with `sgx-sdk`, `sgx-psw` and `sgx-drivers`.

Written by: `hk`
Binary Exploitation.name: sgx flag vault

Binary Exploitation.description:
I found a dns implementation on github for this problem.

`drill -p 54 foo.bar.com @binary.utctf.live`

_by hk_
Binary Exploitation.name: dns

Binary Exploitation.description:
We should cancel all pwners.

`nc binary.utctf.live 9050`

_by jitterbug_
Binary Exploitation.name: Cancelled

Binary Exploitation.description:
You've recently been imprisoned for trying to outpizza the hut. Fortunately, your guard, Simplicio, seems to be pretty smooth brained. 

Note: the flag is in /root/flag.txt.

`nc kernel.utctf.live 9051`

_by jitterbug_
Binary Exploitation.name: Simplicio's Jail

Cryptography.description:
My friend Shamir was trying to share the flag with me and some of the other problem writers, but he wanted to make sure it didn't get intercepted in transmission, so he split it up. He said that the secrets that he shared will help us find the flag, but I can't figure it out! These are the secrets I've gathered so far:

```
(C81E728D9D4C2F636F067F89CC14862C, 31E96A93BF1A7CE1872A3CCDA6E07F86)
(ECCBC87E4B5CE2FE28308FD9F2A7BAF3, ADF6E4F1052BDE978344743CCDCF5771)
(E4DA3B7FBBCE2345D7772B0674A318D5, 0668FBCFE4098FEA0218163AC21E6531)
```

Can you figure out which flag is the right one?

_by balex_
Cryptography.name: Curveball

Cryptography.description:
Found this weird hash function, can you figure it out?

```nc super.utctf.live 9005```

_by dmanc_
Cryptography.name: Weird Walks

Cryptography.description:
Can you make it through all of the encodings?

_by balex_
Cryptography.name: [basics] crypto

Cryptography.description:
Two of my friends were arguing about which CTF category is the best, but they encrypted it because they didn't want anyone to see. Lucky for us, they reused the same key; can you recover it?

Here are the ciphertexts:
```
213c234c2322282057730b32492e720b35732b2124553d354c22352224237f1826283d7b0651

3b3b463829225b3632630b542623767f39674431343b353435412223243b7f162028397a103e
```

_by balex_
Cryptography.name: One True Problem

Cryptography.description:
I found these characters on top of a hill covered with algae ... bruh I can't figure it out can you help me?

```wznqca{d4uqop0fk_q1nwofDbzg_eu}```

by bnuno
Cryptography.name: Hill

Cryptography.description:
Mr. Anshel and Mr. Goldfeld were trying to exchange some asymmetric keys to get a shared key. They aren't very good at math, so they decided to use a Rubik's Cube instead to do the crypto. I don't think it's very secure though, I think you might be able to guess some of their keys :hmm:

```
Mr. A public key: [B' U', F B F, R' D, B D']
Mr. G public key: [R D L', D U' B, U F', L' F]

Mr. A sends: [B D' R' D R D L' D' R D B', B D' R' D D U' B D' R D B', B D' R' D U F' D' R D B', B D' R' D L' F D' R D B']
Mr. G sends: [U F' R D L' B' U' L D' R' F U', U F' R D L' F B F L D' R' F U', U F' R D L' R' D L D' R' F U', U F' R D L' B D' L D' R' F U']
```

**NOTE: The flag is the shared key that they generate, so it is NOT in `utflag{}` format**

_by balex_
Cryptography.name: Cube Crypto

Forensics.description:
A simple image with a couple of twists...

by phleisch
Forensics.name: Observe Closely

Forensics.description:
I recently received this signal transmission known as SSTV in a mode called Martian? This technology is all very old so I'm not sure what to do with it. Could you help me out?

by phleisch
Forensics.name: 1 Frame per Minute

Forensics.description:
My friend said they hid a flag in this picture, but it's broken! Now that I think about it, I don't even know if it really is a picture...

_by balex_
Forensics.name: [basics] forensics

Forensics.description:
I found this audio file, but I don't think it's any song I've ever heard... Maybe there's something else inside?

_by balex_
Forensics.name: Spectre

Forensics.description:
This file seems to be too large given how much text it contains, but I can find zero evidence of the flag. Maybe you'll have better luck than me?

by bnuno
Forensics.name: Zero

Forensics.description:
My friend Hackerman tried to send me a secret transmission, but I think some of it got messed up in transit. Can you fix it?

_by balex_
Forensics.name: The Legend of Hackerman, Pt. 1

Forensics.description:
Ok, I've received another file from Hackerman, but it's just a Word Document? He said that he attached a picture of the flag, but I can't find it...

_by balex_
Forensics.name: The Legend of Hackerman, Pt. 2

Misc.description: The flag is `utflag{this_is_the_flag}`! Welcome to UTCTF!
Misc.name: Sanity Check

Fill out this quick 1-minute survey to get the flag!

[link](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScEPPnT2eVXl_--Ztm4a6HL94_iVPWNxev6YseKbmLUfsh0IA/viewform?usp=sf_link)

Networking.description:
I found some weird data while monitoring my network, but I didn't catch it all. See if you can make sense of it.

_by masond_
Networking.name: Nittaku 3 Star Premium

Networking.description:
One of my servers was compromised, but I can't figure it out. See if you can solve it for me!

_by masond_
Networking.name: Do Not Stop

Networking.description:
I have a pretty cool server, but it's for QUICk people only. Nobody else is allowed.

`54.152.23.18:1337`

Pro Tip: Set your ALPN to "quic-echo-example" because I forgot to remove it.

_by masond_
Networking.name: QUICk Servers

Reverse Engineering.description:
Get all perfect to decrypt the flag.

_by gg_
Reverse Engineering.name: Rhythm Game Vault

Reverse Engineering.description:
You've been contracted to check an IoT vault for a potential backdoor. Your goal is to figure out the sequence that unlocks the vault and use it to create the flag. Unfortunately, you were unable to acquire the hardware and only have a schematic drawn by the vault company's intern, a firmware dump and the model number of the microcontroller.

The flag has the following format:
utflag{P<PORT_LETTER><PORT_NUMBER>} , ex:
utflag{PD0,PD2}

by Dan
Reverse Engineering.name: The Securest Vault ™

Reverse Engineering.description:
Convince your crush to go out with you. Note: the flag is what you need to say to convince him/her to go out with you.

_by jitterbug_
Reverse Engineering.name: Crack the Heart

Reverse Engineering.description:
We found this snippet of code on our employee's laptop. It looks really scary. Can you figure out what it does?

Written by `hk`
Reverse Engineering.name: IR

Reverse Engineering.description:
I know there's a string in this binary somewhere.... Now where did I leave it?

_by balex_

In an effort to get rid of all of the bloat in the .png format, I'm proud to announce .PNG2! The first pixel is #7F7F7F, can you get the rest of the image?

Web.description:

Shrek seems to be pretty angry about something, so he deleted some important information off his site. He murmured something about Donkey being too *committed* to infiltrate his swamp. Can you *checkout* the site and see what the *status* is?

Web.description:
After announcing that he would be having an anonymous 1-on-1 AMA with randomly chosen, adoring fans, an engineering team hacked together a web app and likely forget to patch some obvious security holes. Anyway, you're one of the lucky fans chosen to chatt with Bratt Pid! Have fun: [web3.utctf.live:8080](http://web3.utctf.live:8080)

_by phleisch_
Web.name: Chatt with Bratt
